transcripts.text: Tonight, I wanted to talk about the double slit experiment.  I had heard an earlier caller speak about how that proved God.  I believe that the double slit experiment proves that there's no such thing as an all seeing God, because what happens is the results change based on observation.  And that means that God is not observing.
Okay.  Well, I might actually have to disagree with you and that last caller.  I don't think this experiment proves or disproves the existence of a God.  And to be fair, I'm not...
I didn't say a God, though.  I said an all-seeing God.
Oh, an all-seeing God.  Okay, that's more specific.  That makes more sense.  That's more justified.  Okay.  What would your take on that be?

You know, so when people are talking about the double slit experiment, they're talking about depending on your observation, your point of view, you're getting different things.  That's not quite what that data says.
Can we briefly, what is the double slit experiment?  Because I'm unfamiliar with it.  I don't want to pretend I know about it.
Maybe Glenn.  Glenn, are you an expert on the double slit experiment?  Do you want to give a take?  Did you teach me?  Yeah.

Yeah, not an expert, but I've watched a lot of videos on it.  It's very interesting.  It's so hard to understand.  The only thing it does prove is what I'm suggesting, in my opinion.  But what it is, is they shoot a particle or an electron through a double slit, and it will form a wave pattern on a screen behind the double slit if you don't observe it.  But if you observe it, and observing could be a person, it could be a camera.  If you actually observe it, you could see the individual particle form a particle pattern.  So the patterns that it will form will change based on observation.  It's the most interesting thing about quantum physics that people just don't don't don't don't explain.  here's.  the other thing i think it proves is the know all seeing god.

here's the thing that people don't point out with the double slit experiment is that in the act of observation things are still happening on a physical level that we don't always think about.  photons are still bouncing off of this thing so that we could see it with our eyes or or that our machines are still detecting stuff There's still physical – there's physics that happen in the actual action of observation.  And that's what drives me crazy because I don't – because obviously there's a lot of quantum woo out there of people saying like – I saw in that book today that I was talking about earlier.  There was some stuff about quantum physics in there.  By the way, did you know there's a quantum university in Honolulu, Hawaii?  Yeah.  Isn't that crazy?  Quantum University.  I want to be a Quantum U alumni.  You think if I asked if they could make me like an honorary thing, I could say I'm from Quantum U because that sounds cool.  Do you think like they're – I don't know.  I could talk about this all day.  Like their mascots are like the neutrinos or something?  That would be awesome.  I don't know.  That would be cool.  Anyway, side note.  So yeah, like – You know, people just misinterpret this thing all over the place.  And, Glenn, you're right to point out that, like, there's so many different – there's as many interpretations to the double slit experiment as there are to, you know, the act of observing the particles, right?  It's not clear.  And certainly the people like us who don't have – you know, a relevant degree in the field of talking about, shouldn't be even talking about it as well, but the fact that so many other people are talking about it, right, is something that we have to bring up and have to carefully scrutinize.
Yeah, I don't have anything, I don't have anything past a high school diploma, so I can't be, you know, teaching people about quantum mechanics and stuff, but, uh...
Even the experts don't understand it.  It's fascinating.

Yeah, it's certainly not fully realized, and there's different interpretations on how to look at the data there.  But does it prove that there's a God?  Certainly, as you point out, it can't be an all-seeing God if it's two different states, right?  Was that kind of the argument you were going to go there?
Yeah, that was my comment, though.  I just believe it proves that there's not an all-seeing God because I have heard the all-seeing God used before.
Yeah.
Okay.

Yeah, people will talk about that and they'll talk about superposition and stuff, you know, and particles being able to speak to each other at different places and use quantum mechanics to explain healing in the body and consciousness and just all kinds of just nonsense.  that doesn't really...
It sounds like what you're saying is you can confidently rule out a specific divine attribute, which I would agree with, so... Yeah, I don't think we're in disagreement here.

That's the main comment.  Yeah.  Yeah, that's the main comment I was making too.  And the other thing you just touched on was spooky action at a distance.  Yeah, spooky action at a distance.  Yeah, very fascinating.
Yeah, it's fascinating.  Again, I'll say it once and I'll say it again.  The people who study these things are not saying the things that other people are saying about it.  You know what I mean?
And it's easy to miss about them.
They don't know.  Nobody has a solution.  Even the smartest people would like a solution.  If you could ask somebody the question that could give you an answer, you'd be in really good shape.

Yeah, for sure.  But again, I want to leave it to the... I'll talk about science all day, but at the end of the day, I'm going to... Let the experts have their say because I can't write a book about this stuff.  At best, I can do a research paper, but it's not the same thing.  So anyway, Glenn, glad you got to call.  Yeah, thank you.  And point that out and bring us some sanity into this world.  I'll let you go now.  Thanks again for calling in.  And on that note, I think we should wrap it up here.  All right.  So tonight, again, we're going to be talking on Discord in just a bit.  So those of you who are watching live, come stick around.  And Shane is here to answer any questions.  Thanks again for joining us today.
Thank you, man.  Thank you for having me on.  Yeah.  Hopefully we can do it again.  And I got to get you on Atheist Vanguard sometime.

Yeah, we'll make it happen.  Yeah.  I'd be interested in doing that.  So remember, folks, next week is the last episode of Truth Wanted.  For the year.  It's going to be Friday the 13th with Jamie Boone as my guest.  Who's that?  Who's that?  Yeah, yeah, yeah.
